course_title: Research Design in the Social Sciences

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding and application of research design principles in the social sciences.
Demonstrate an understanding and application of methodological approaches to research in the social sciences.
Demonstrate an understanding of the role of evidence in social science research and its application to your project.
Demonstrate the capacity to plan and manage a complex project.
Demonstrate the capacity to communicate your research design in written and oral form.
Demonstrate a capacity to communicate research benefit to a range of audiences.
Demonstrate the capacity to engage with evidence and literature relevant to your discipline.

assessments.assessment_title: Thesis outline/structure document submission and peer feedback participation
assessments.due_date:
13/03/2026 - 20/03/2026

one-page thesis outline due 2pm 13/03/2026. Peer feedback session due in-class on 20/03/2026.
assessments.task_description: Marking criteria for this item is available on the course learning site. At the successful completion of the task students will be awarded 10%. To be awarded the 10% a student must have submitted their thesis outline document (week 3), and participated in the peer feedback session in the week 4 class, which includes completing and submitting their peer feedback sheet to the course coordinator at the end of the week 4 class. Templates for both task are available on the course learning site.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students are to submit their one page thesis outline through the course blackboard site in the Assessment content folder in week 3 by Friday 13-03-26, 2 pm.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: Students are required to complete 2 modules from the list of on-line modules available in the course learning site. Students can pick any from the list of modules that are available, and these two modules can be completed at any time during the semester, but the two must be completed by week 12. It is suggested students should consult with their honours supervisor as to the most applicable and useful modules to undertake. The completion of the two research modules will be recorded in grade centre.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Discipline specific research proposal on thesis topic
assessments.task_description:
Students are required to write up a research proposal based on their thesis topic. Students should format their proposal according to the proposal template as provided. Proposals should be no more than a maximum of 8 pages long (includes references) in 12 point font, 1.5 spaced. Reference list can be in 10 point font. Requirements for this piece of assessment will be outlined in week 1 and course content will cover different components of the research proposal. 

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in the course learning site.

Use of AI: Artificial Intelligence (AI) provides emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI in each instance. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
During weeks 9-13 students are required to complete an in-class presentation on their thesis topic which covers aims, background, methods and expected outcomes. Timeline for individual presentation will be 15 minutes and this will include a Q & A based on questions provided by your supervisor and the class.

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in the course learning site.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be complete in class on a set week as allocated by the course cooridinator
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Course introduction and aims.

·      What is research design?

·      Aims of social science research.

·      Structure of a research honours thesis (and viva).

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Course introduction and aims. ·      What is research design? ·      Aims of social science research. ·      Structure of a research honours thesis (and viva).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Formulating research aims and questions.

·      What are research aims?

·      What are research questions?

·      What are hypothesises?

·      The aims of a literature review (framing your proposal/project).

Archaeology students – discipline specific class - Honours grant writing for archaeology with developing your research question
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Formulating research aims and questions. ·      What are research aims? ·      What are research questions? ·      What are hypothesises? ·      The aims of a literature review (framing your proposal/project). Archaeology students – discipline specific class - Honours grant writing for archaeology with developing your research question

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Research ethics

·      What is low risk research.

·      What is high risk research. 

·      Informed consent.

·      Research ethics across disciplines – panel discussion.

Thesis structure document due (includes stating aims, questions and brief outline of theoretical framework).
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Research ethics ·      What is low risk research. ·      What is high risk research. ·      Informed consent. ·      Research ethics across disciplines – panel discussion. Thesis structure document due (includes stating aims, questions and brief outline of theoretical framework).

·      A/Prof Suzanna Fay

·      Peer to peer feedback session on thesis structure document.

learning_activities.topic:

·      Quantitative methods.

·      What are variables.

·      Quantitative design. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

·      Qualitative methods.

·      Coding process and thematic analysis.

·      Writing style and common mistakes

·      Developing dissemination strategies for different stakeholders and end-users.

·      Exercise - producing your thesis (Dr Caitlin D'Gluyas)
